data.text: Schwalbe Marathon Tires Popped off the Rim

Has anyone had any issues with bike tyres popping off the rim? I fitted Schwalbe marathon winters and they were quite loose. Pumped them up and in the morning the rear had popped off. I refitted it. Now today while riding the rear popped off again and there is clear damage to the bead - need a new tyre…
Narrow rim pehaps? Take a look this chart.
data.author: Pedro DE Aragao

data.text: could be - thanks! It’s nominally a 50mm tyre which is the same as came on the bike originally, but may well be wider in practice… The wire bead actually ripped through the carcass of the tyre quite spectacularly - I’m quite glad it went my front wheel!
data.author: David Tetris

data.text: Could be an old tyre with dry rubber also, witch falls apart when assabled

data.author: Pedro DE Aragao

data.text: It's unlikely to be the issue, but it's worth checking you don't have hookless rims!
data.author: Rob Gardiner

data.text: I had a problem with a continental tire. I think it was caused when I went over a french drain with slots. I went down hill slowly but my tire must have caught between the slots and it pulled out of the rim. I fixed it and I was able to ride it but it was not reliable so I changed it.
data.author: Jean Phillips

data.text: I would return the tire. Schwalbe is good with customer service! It happened once to me about 5 years ago. But, it’s a fluke. When installing, you also just have to make sure they are evenly placed throughout the rim. I think either that or the the improper way I installed them with my tire iron was the culprit. In any case, haven’t had any issues since installing properly, but their customer service is definitely good to allow you to try another tire
data.author: Steve S Gordon

data.text: With wheel off bike, Wiggle uninflated all around to make sure bead is seated evenly, pump up just until squishy, roll wheel around with downward pressure, pump up some more, roll around some more, pump all the way up
data.author: Alan Pittman

data.text: I've had the opposite problem: getting over-tight replacement tires onto rims using a normal travelling toolset. As in your case, I ended up trashing the tyres. I was led to wonder if there are tyres meant (initially) to be fitted using a workshop stretching machine, and others using normal tools (looser fit).
data.author: Douglas Hope
